articleContent.title: Chord: 11th in G# (Shape: G)
articleContent.content:
## Chord: 11th in G# (Shape: G)

### Description:
The G#11 chord is a complex chord that includes the notes G#, C#, D#, F#, and A#. The 11th note in this chord, in this case D# is added on top of the standard 1st, 3rd, 5th, and (sometimes) 7th. Its shape is based on a G major chord, making it a rich and colorful harmony that adds depth and tension to a progression.

### Notes and Intervals:
- G# (Root)
- C# (Major 3rd)
- D# (Perfect 4th/11th)
- F# (Major 6th/13th)
- A# (Major 9th)

### Musical Flavor:
The G#11 chord has a jazzy and sophisticated sound due to its dissonant nature created by the added 4th/11th interval. It can add a sense of mystery and intrigue to a chord progression or serve as a colorful embellishment in various musical contexts.

### Genre and Usage:
The G#11 chord is commonly used in jazz, funk, and R&B genres where complex harmonies are appreciated. It can be found in both chord progressions and as a voicing in improvisational settings, adding a unique flavor to the music.

### Songs:
1. "Cantaloupe Island" by Herbie Hancock
2. "So What" by Miles Davis
3. "I Want You Back" by The Jackson 5
